title: AquaNeRF: Neural Radiance Fields in Underwater Media with Distractor Removal
author: Luca Gough (Visual Information Laboratory, University of Bristol), Adrian Azzarelli (University of Bristol), Fan Zhang (University of Bristol), Nantheera Anantrasirichai (University of Bristol), ...
relevance_why: The innovations presented for improving visual rendering in underwater environments could inspire similar techniques for audio rendering and enhancement tasks in mixed or complex audio environments.
background: Modeling underwater scenes to improve visualization of static objects while reducing the influence of dynamic artifacts and particles in footage.
contribution: AquaNeRF introduces a novel renderer and optimization scheme for rendering underwater scenes, achieving improved performance by reducing visual artifacts and enhancing static target details.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods like SeaThru-NeRF and RobustNeRF struggle with dynamic occlusions and transient clutter, producing artifacts in renders.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work utilizes a single Gaussian distribution to model transmittance, significantly stabilizing optimization by focusing on static geometry rather than dynamic distractions.

key_innovation: The method effectively confines the rendering focus to a single surface per ray, reducing noise from moving objects and enhancing visualization quality.
real_world_impact: By improving underwater scene rendering, this research has potential applications in marine biology, underwater archaeology, and environmental monitoring, aiding in better visual analysis of ocean life.
limitations: The method may struggle with rays from distant cameras that attenuate, leading to blurred and less color-accurate reconstructions.

new_terms.Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF): **Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF)** is a method for representing and rendering scenes using a neural network to model volumetric scene properties and view-dependent appearance.
new_terms.Gaussian weight function: **Gaussian weight function** is a statistical function used to describe the distribution of transmittance around a mean point, allowing for better surface geometry modeling in rendering tasks.
